author: Anabel DÌez

original: Asç_; menciona la aprobaciç_n de la Ley del referçÈndum y de la Ley de transitoriedad jurç_dica y fundaciç_n de la Repç_blica.

original: TambiçÈn; la celebraciç_n de un referçÈndum que califica de -ilegal- y que se considera no celebrado por carecer de -cualquier garantç_a-.

original: Si Puigdemont no atiende el requerimiento del Gobierno; Rajoy tendrç_ que enviar al Senado un plan detallado de las competencias que quiere asumir del Govern.

original: POLççTICA PRIMER PASO PARA ACTIVAR EL ARTççCULO 155 Rajoy da cinco dç_as al Govern para que aclare si hay independencia Las medidas legales que prepara el Gobierno para frenar la declaraciç_n de independencia en diferido Puigdemont declara la independencia de Cataluç_a pero la deja en suspenso y pide diç_logo El Govern: -Si el Gobierno aplica el 155; querrç_ decir que no hay voluntad de diç_logo- Pedro Sç_nchez da una comparecencia a las 12.30 horas sobre Cataluç_a Rajoy pregunta a Cataluç_a si ha declarado la independencia antes de aplicar el 155 POR D.ESPERANZAMADRID Actualizado: 12/10/2017 00:13 horas El presidente del Gobierno; Mariano Rajoy quiere ofrecer certezas a los espaç_oles; -especialmente a los catalanes-; ha dicho.

original: Rajoy aclarç_ este miçÈrcoles que en funciç_n de la respuesta que dçÈ el Govern de Carles Puigdemont; el Ejecutivo decidirç_ los siguientes pasos a dar.

author: D. Esperanza
original: El Gobierno ha dado un plazo de cinco dç_as al presidente catalç_n (hasta el prç_ximo lunes a las 10 de la maç_ana) para que confirme si ha declarado la independencia de Cataluç_a y fija un segundo plazo; hasta el jueves; 19 de octubre (tambiçÈn hasta las 10) para que; en el supuesto de que lo haya hecho; rectifique y evite asç_ su aplicaciç_n.

original: En dicho documento se reclama a Puigdemont que -comunique el presente requerimiento- a la presidenta del Parlament; Carme Forcadell; y a la Mesa de la cç_mara catalana; -requiriçÈndoles igualmente la restauraciç_n del orden constitucional y estatutario; en los mismos tçÈrminos realizados al presidente y al gobierno de Cataluç_a-.

original: El Gobierno ha dado asç_ un primer paso hacia la puesta en marcha del artç_culo 155 de la constituciç_n.

author: D. Esperanza
original: Consejo de Ministros extraordinario El presidente del Gobierno habç_a convocado este miçÈrcoles a las 9.00 horas un Consejo de Ministros extraordinario para abordar las opciones que hay para atajar el desafç_o independentista de Cataluç_a tras el anuncio del presidente de la Generalitat; Carles Puigdemont; de suspender la declaraciç_n de independencia durante unas semanas para buscar la mediaciç_n unas horas antes de su intervenciç_n en el Congreso.

author: D. Esperanza
original: Asç_ lo anunciç_ anoche la vicepresidenta del Gobierno; Soraya Sç_enz de Santamarç_a en una comparecencia en el Palacio de la Moncloa en la que criticç_ duramente que Puigdemont quiera -imponer una mediaciç_n- sin -volver a la legalidad-.

author: D. Esperanza
original: Segç_n recalcç_; el diç_logo entre demç_cratas debe producirse dentro de la ley y respetando las reglas del juego.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Spain asks Catalonia: Did you declare independence or not?Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy leaves a cabinet meeting in Madrid on Wednesday.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: (AFP/Getty Images) By Pamela Rolfe and James McAuley October 11 at 2:16 PM  MADRID _¢´ Spain_¢ès prime minister on Wednesday asked the head of the secession-minded Catalonia region the question that no one can seem to answer: Did he declare independence or not?

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: The query reflected more than just confusion.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Clarity on Catalonia_¢ès position is critical for Spain to map out its next move _¢´ including possible harsh measures against Catalonia if it proclaims itself a sovereign nation.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: The uncertainty comes after the region_¢ès president; Carles Puigdemont; told the Catalan Parliament in Barcelona on Tuesday that Catalonia had the right to be an independent country; citing a disputed referendum last week that showed strong support for secession from Spain.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: [Catalan president stops short of declaring independence] But instead of an outright declaration; Puigdemont said the ìeffectî of independence would be delayed for several weeks to facilitate further dialogue with Madrid.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: He then signed a document that some perceived as formalizing a break from Spain; baffling observers in Barcelona and Madrid alike.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Play Video 3:16 What's happening in Spain and how did we get here?

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: 0:00 After a tumultuous Oct. 1 referendum; Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont stopped short of declaring independence from Spain.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: (The Washington Post) On Wednesday; Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy accused Puigdemont of sowing ìdeliberate confusion.î He also asked the Catalan leader to clarify his position.îThis call _¢´ before any of the measures that the government may adopt under Article 155 of our constitution _¢´ seeks to offer citizens the clarity and security that a question of such importance requires;î Rajoy said in a speech.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Article 155 of Spain_¢ès constitution; known as the ìnuclear option;î allows Madrid to suspend Catalonia_¢ès devolved government and take over running the region should it declare independence.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: On Wednesday; the Spanish government appeared to close the door on any offer of negotiation but notably did not proceed with activating Article 155.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìI am a firm supporter of dialogue; but I should advise that it is not possible under the guise of dialogue to accept the unilateral imposition of points of view;î Rajoy said in his speech.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìThere is no possible mediation between democratic law and disobedience and illegality.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: We are not talking about different interpretations of the law.î Spain_¢ès Constitutional Court had ruled the independence referendum illegal; but Catalan authorities proceeded anyway.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: In the end; the vast majority of those who participated in the vote backed secession; but fewer than 50 percent of Catalan residents cast ballots.The recent call for Catalan independence represents the biggest constitutional crisis in Spain since the regime of dictator Francisco Franco ended in 1975.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: It also highlights a rising separatist tide in a troubled European Union struggling to navigate a historic migrant crisis and continued economic malaise.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: [What you need to know about the vote in Catalonia] In his extended address to the Spanish parliament; Rajoy reiterated that the Oct. 1 Catalan referendum was illegal.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìVoting is a part of democracy; but a vote against democracy or outside a democracy is not democracy;î he said.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìThe farce that took place Oct. 1 was not democracy.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: It was an exercise against democracy.î In response to Puigdemont_¢ès request for ìdialogue;î Rajoy was firm that Spain would not discuss options outside the legal parameters of its constitution.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìWithout a doubt; you can dialogue in a situation like this; to improve the framework of living together; but within the framework of the existing conditions;î he said.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìNever in its history have Catalonia_¢ès citizens had more freedom.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: The independence movement is about to throw away the best period of Catalonia in its entire history.î It was not clear whether or when Puigdemont would respond to Rajoy.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Puigdemont has until Monday to clarify his position; according to the Spanish government_¢ès formal request to the regional leader.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: If he declines to answer or says that he has declared independence; the Spanish government will give him until Oct. 19 to rethink his position and return Catalonia to the rule of law.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: If that maneuver fails; Rajoy intends to start the necessary procedures to activate Article 155.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: [Spain_¢ès king calls independence vote _¢_totally outside law and democracy_¢è ] Catalan authorities said; however; that independence was inevitable and that it was up to Madrid to negotiate the best possible deal.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Josep Rull; the Catalan government_¢ès secretary of territory and sustainability; told reporters; ìIt_¢ès not time to ask questions; but to give answers.î Likewise; in an interview on Spanish radio; Jordi Turull; a member of the Catalan Parliament; said the dialogue that Puigdemont seeks is about how _¢´ not whether _¢´ to separate from Spain.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Today's WorldView What's most important from where the world meets Washington ìWe want to talk about Catalan independence;î Turull said.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìOur commitment is irrefutable.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: We don_¢èt want to trick anyone.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: We want to see if it_¢ès possible to do it in a dialogued and agreed-upon way; to see what the state proposes for Catalonia.î In Madrid; however; the only consensus was that an independent Catalonia would never come to pass.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: Even leading members of the opposition joined ranks with Rajoy to condemn the push for secession.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìWe cannot accept unilateral declarations.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: We are not going to accept that anyone breaks the law;î said Margarita Robles; a leader of the Spanish Socialist Workers_¢è Party; the principal opposition party.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: ìAnd that is why we have asked the [Catalan] government to return to the constitutional framework.

author: Pamela Rolfe
original: In this constitutional framework we all fit.î McAuley reported from Paris.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Spain Asks Catalonia: Did You Declare Independence or Not?

author: Raphael Minder
original: By RAPHAEL MINDEROCT.

author: Raphael Minder
original: 11; 2017 Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain delivered a statement in Madrid on Wednesday; saying; ìIt is urgent to put an end to the situation that Catalonia is living.î Credit Paul White/Associated Press BARCELONA; Spain _¢´ Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain took a tentative step on Wednesday toward seizing administrative control of Catalonia; but he asked the region_¢ès leader to first clarify whether he had actually declared independence from the rest of the country following an unusual series of events the night before.

author: Raphael Minder
original: In a short news conference; Mr. Rajoy called on Carles Puigdemont; Catalonia_¢ès leader; to confirm his intentions; given what the prime minister called ìthe deliberate confusionî generated by the comments and actions of Mr. Puigdemont and other Catalan leaders on Tuesday.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Pending a response from the Catalan government; Mr. Rajoy said he was initiating a request for his government to invoke Article 155 of the Spanish Constitution _¢´ a broad tool that has never been used.

author: Raphael Minder
original: The article would allow Madrid to suspend Catalan lawmakers and take charge of the region_¢ès autonomous administration.

author: Raphael Minder
original: But Mr. Rajoy_¢ès action did not commit his government to an emergency intervention; and Mr. Puigdemont was given until Monday morning to respond.

author: Raphael Minder
original: ìIt is urgent to put an end to the situation that Catalonia is living;î Mr. Rajoy said.

author: Raphael Minder
original: ìThe government wants to offer certainties to Spaniards and Catalans; in particular.

author: Raphael Minder
original: In Catalonia; a Declaration of Independence From Spain (Sort of) OCT. 10; 2017 Catalonia Government Declares Overwhelming Vote for Independence OCT. 6; 2017 Catalonia_¢ès Independence Vote Descends Into Chaos and Clashes OCT. 1; 2017 Catalonia Independence Bid Pushes Spain Toward Crisis SEPT. 8; 2017 Continue reading the main story Mr. Rajoy; whose remarks came after an emergency cabinet meeting earlier in the day about how to address the situation in Catalonia; addressed the Spanish Parliament later in the day.

author: Raphael Minder
original: While Mr. Puigdemont is facing a fight for his own political survival _¢´ hard-line separatists have denounced his failure to deliver a clear message of independence _¢´ Mr. Rajoy appears to have consolidated his power base in Madrid; where he has been in charge of a minority government since late 2016.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Spain_¢ès main opposition Socialist party expressed support for Mr. Rajoy as he discussed using Article 155; an idea it has been more reluctant to endorse in the past.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Pedro Sç_nchez; the Socialist leader; said at a news conference that his party also supported Mr. Rajoy in his demands ìto clarify and get out of the quagmire in which Mr. Puigdemont has put Catalan politics.î Mr. Sç_nchez also said he had reached an agreement with Mr. Rajoy to form a commission on changing the Constitution.

author: Raphael Minder
original: ìThe Spain of 2017 is not the same as that of 1978;î he said; referring to the year the document enshrined Spain_¢ès return to democracy.

author: Raphael Minder
original: The commission is not expected to complete its preliminary report for six months; however; so its work is likely to have little influence on the conflict with the Catalan separatists.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Mr. Rajoy is under intense pressure from his own lawmakers to stop Catalan secessionism in its tracks; but he is also aware that strong reprisals against Mr. Puigdemont could galvanize the independence movement.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Mr. Rajoy_¢ès comments on Wednesday were his first formal response to the events of the previous evening; when Mr. Puigdemont appeared to declare independence from Spain in an address to the Catalan Parliament _¢´ then immediately suspended that decision to allow for more ìdialogueî with Madrid.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Further muddying the waters; Mr. Puigdemont and separatist lawmakers later signed a declaration of independence; a step set in motion by a highly disputed referendum on Oct. 1 that went ahead despite being suspended by the Spanish Constitutional Court.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Newsletter Sign UpContinue reading the main story The Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week.You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services.

author: Raphael Minder
original: SEE SAMPLE PRIVACY POLICY OPT OUT OR CONTACT US ANYTIME During Wednesday_¢ès parliamentary debate; Mr. Rajoy insisted that Spain didn_¢èt need outside help to resolve an issue of national sovereignty _¢´ a view that was also backed by the Socialists.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Margarita Robles; the parliamentary spokeswoman for the Socialists; said that Spain_¢ès problems should be handled by its own lawmakers.

author: Raphael Minder
original: ìWe don_¢èt need more mediators than ourselves;î she said.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Most Madridîbased newspapers and television talk shows ridiculed Mr. Puigdemont_¢ès speech on Tuesday and described his call for negotiations with Madrid as an act of desperation.

author: Raphael Minder
original: The headline in El Mundo described the night_¢ès events as ìfarce and blackmail.î Susanna Griso; a news anchor on Antena 3; said the Catalan parliamentary session swung ìbetween tragedy and comedy.î Spanish legal experts say that if Mr. Puigdemont confirms that the region is declaring independence; Mr. Rajoy will almost certainly intervene forcefully in Catalonia.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Mr. Rajoy; who has stood firm against the separatists; has a battery of potential emergency measures available to him.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Along with Article 155; there is also a national emergency law that his government enacted in 2015.

author: Raphael Minder
original: But the prime minister has a long record as a cautious politician who has stayed on the front line of Spanish politics for two decades by steering clear of difficult decisions and letting rivals dig themselves into holes.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Mr. Rajoy said on Wednesday that he would ìcontinue to act with prudenceî and put the onus on Mr. Puigdemont to explain himself.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Mr. Rajoy also argued that the Catalan separatists had never gotten a majority of votes in an election to justify secession; and so could not claim to be acting in the name of the Catalan people.

author: Raphael Minder
original: He told lawmakers Mr. Puigdemont had sought to justify independence based on an ìillegal and fraudulent referendum.îìWhat is not legal isn_¢èt democratic;î he said.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Invoking Article 155; which requires Senate approval; would allow Mr. Rajoy to suspend the political institutions of Catalonia for as long as he believes necessary; including its regional government and Parliament.

author: Raphael Minder
original: His government could also take over the leadership of the region_¢ès autonomous police force and its public broadcaster.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Mr. Rajoy told lawmakers on Wednesday that the separatists should be held responsible for hurting Catalonia_¢ès economy and leading major companies to relocate outside the region because of the legal uncertainty generated by possible secession.

author: Raphael Minder
original: He said Barcelona; Spain_¢ès tourism hub; was suffering as foreigners worried about street unrest.

author: Raphael Minder
original: ìThere have been more travel warnings issued because of the unrest than because of the terrorist attacks;î Mr. Rajoy told Parliament; referring to the attacks that killed 16 people in August; most of them on Barcelona_¢ès most famous promenade.

author: Raphael Minder
original: Separately; public prosecutors could open criminal proceedings against Mr. Puigdemont and his government.

author: Raphael Minder
original: On Monday; Pablo Casado; the spokesman for Mr. Rajoy_¢ès governing party; warned that Mr. Puigdemont could be imprisoned for insurrection.

author: Raphael Minder
original: But Ignacio Gonzç_lez Vega; a spokesman for an association of Spanish judges; warned on Wednesday that ìa political issue cannot be resolved only by applying laws.î He told Antena 3 that Mr. Rajoy ìwill have to step in with a lot of sensitivity; because these measures are very serious.î

author: Sam Jones
original: Spanish PM asks Catalonia: have you declared independence or not?

author: Sam Jones
original: Mariano Rajoy considers suspending region_¢ès autonomy as he accuses Catalan president of deliberately sowing confusion.

author: Sam Jones
original: he Spanish prime minister; Mariano Rajoy; has refused to rule out imposing direct rule over Catalonia.

author: Sam Jones
original: Photograph: Angel Diaz/EPA Wednesday 11 October 2017 17.43 BST First published on Wednesday 11 October 2017 07.50 BST The Spanish prime minister; Mariano Rajoy; has asked the Catalan government to clarify whether or not it has declared independence; as he considers the unprecedented step of suspending the region_¢ès autonomy and imposing direct rule from Madrid.

author: Sam Jones
original: On Tuesday evening; the Catalan president; Carles Puigdemont; said while the referendum this month had given his government a mandate to create a sovereign republic; he would not immediately push ahead with independence from Spain.

author: Sam Jones
original: Analysis Puigdemont speech gives no clarity on Catalan independenceCatalonia_¢ès president has called to _¢_suspend effects of independence declaration_¢è _¢_ potentially upsetting both sides of debate  Read more Although he signed a declaration of independence; he proposed that its effects be suspended for a few weeks to allow for dialogue.

author: Sam Jones
original: Rajoy; who has refused to rule out invoking article 155 of the Spanish constitution to take control of Catalonia; was quick to seize on the ambiguity of Puigdemont_¢ès position; accusing him of deliberately sowing confusion.

author: Sam Jones
original: The prime minister also rejected calls for external mediation between the two governments; insisting the Catalan question remained a domestic matter.

author: Sam Jones
original: ìThe cabinet has agreed this morning to formally require the Catalan government to confirm whether it has declared independence after the deliberate confusion created over whether it has come into effect;î he said in a television address on Wednesday.

author: Sam Jones
original: ìThis request; which comes before any of the measures that the government could adopt under article 155 of our constitution; is meant to offer our citizens the clarity and security that such an important issue requires.î Rajoy said the ball was now firmly back in Puigdemont_¢ès court.

author: Sam Jones
original: ìThe Catalan president_¢ès answer to these questions will inform what happens over the next few days;î he said.

author: Sam Jones
original: ìIf Mr Puigdemont demonstrates a willingness to respect the law and re-establish institutional normality; we could bring a close to a period of instability; tension and the breakdown of co-existence.

author: Sam Jones
original: ìThat is what everyone wants and expects; it_¢ès what they_¢ève been demanding.

author: Sam Jones
original: We must put an urgent end to the situation in Catalonia.

author: Sam Jones
original: There must be a return to normality and calm as swiftly as possible.î Speaking later on Wednesday; Pedro Sç_nchez; the leader of Spain_¢ès Socialist party (PSOE); urged Puigdemont to ìbe black and whiteî about whether independence had been declared but offered a possible way out of the crisis.

author: Sam Jones
original: If independence had been declared; said Sç_nchez; then the PSOE would back the actions of the Spanish government.

author: Sam Jones
original: But he also said that he and Rajoy had agreed that there should be a commission to examine the possibility of changing the way the country_¢ès autonomous regions are governed through constitutional reform.

author: Sam Jones
original: The idea; Sç_nchez added; was to find a formula to ìallow for Catalonia to remain a part of Spainî.

author: Sam Jones
original: While talks on the matter will not begin for six months _¢_ meaning there is still ample scope to apply article 155 _¢_ the move could go some way to showing that negotiations are possible if Puigdemont backs away from independence.

author: Sam Jones
original: It also shows that Rajoy and Sç_nchez are increasingly united in the face of the secessionist threat.

author: Sam Jones
original: I am Catalan: 'It's about building a new society for all' _¢_ video In an address to parliament on Wednesday afternoon; Rajoy described the referendum as an ìillegal and fraudulentî act; dismissed Puigdemont_¢ès independence plans as a ìfairytaleî and said Spain would resolve the standoff on its own.

author: Sam Jones
original: After the Catalan referendum: what happens next?Read more He was adamant that there could be no discussion of Spain_¢ès national unity as laid out in the constitution.

author: Sam Jones
original: ìThat_¢ès something that the many mediators who have offered themselves over recent days should bear in mind;î he said.

author: Sam Jones
original: ìMost of them have offered to help in good faith to find a way out of this situation.

author: Sam Jones
original: I can only thank them for their concern and their interest.

author: Sam Jones
original: But there is no possible mediation between democratic law and disobedience or illegality.î He has repeatedly pointed out that the referendum and the laws underpinning it are a violation of the Spanish constitution; which is based ìon the indissoluble unity of the Spanish nation; the common and indivisible homeland of all Spaniardsî Why does the Spanish government say the Catalan referendum is illegal?

author: Sam Jones
original: Barring a sudden climbdown from Puigdemont; Rajoy looks likely to become the first Spanish prime minister to take the drastic step of invoking article 155.

author: Sam Jones

author: Jon Rogers
original: Catalonia crisis: Rajoy opens way to suspending region_¢ès self-rule MARIANO Rajoy has asked Catalonia_¢ès president to clarify whether or not he has declared independence as he prepares the way to possibly impose the suspension of the region_¢ès self-rule.

author: Jon Rogers
original: By JON ROGERS PUBLISHED: 18:09; Wed; Oct 11; 2017 | UPDATED: 18:09; Wed; Oct 11; 2017 The Spanish prime minister made the announcement after holding an extraordinary meeting of the Council of Ministers in Madrid and followed Carles Puigdemont_¢ès announcement in the Catalan parliament that independence had been declared before taking the unusual step of putting it on hold in order to have talks with the central Spanish administration.Madrid could impose central control of the north east region under Article 155 of the Spanish constitution which gives Mr Rajoy_¢ès conservative government the power to remove Catalonia_¢ès power of self-rule.

author: Jon Rogers
original: Imposing Article 155 would be considered a ìfederal coercionî and is seen as the _¢ènuclear option_¢è but could see a strong reaction from Catalonia if it was implemented.

author: Jon Rogers
original: Mariano Rajoy (L) has asked Carles Puigdemont to clarify the question of Catalan independence The Constitution states: ìIf an Autonomous Community does not fulfil the obligations imposed by the Constitution or other laws or acts in a way that seriously undermines the general interest of Spain; the Government; upon previous request to the President of the Autonomous Community and; in the case of not being attended; with the approval by an absolute majority of the Senate; may adopt the necessary measures to force the latter to enforce those obligations or to protect general interest.î Mr Rajoy in his statement said: ìIf Mr Puigdemont stresses his will to respect the legality and re-establish the institutional normality; this would put an end to a period of instability; tensions and breach of coexistence.î However he did not respond to Mr Puigdemont_¢ès repeated call for him to sit round a table for talks on the issue of independence.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: Spain Turns Screws on Catalans With Threat of Direct Control By Angeline Benoit ; Todd White ; and Charles Penty October 11; 2017; 2:30 PM GMT+4 October 11; 2017; 7:50 PM GMT+4 Rajoy starts process of asserting control over rebel region Spanish government responds to Catalan President Puigdemont Rajoy Seeks Clarity on Catalonia Independence Bid Rajoy Seeks Clarity on Catalonia Independence Bid Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy stepped up pressure on Catalonia to halt its drive for independence; taking the first step in a process that could strip the region_¢ès separatist government of its limited autonomy and impose direct control from Madrid.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: Rajoy convened an emergency session of cabinet on Wednesday; at which ministers agreed to issue a formal request to the Catalan government for confirmation of whether it had declared independence.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: Rajoy cited ìdeliberate confusionî sown by the regional administration in Barcelona the previous day.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: Catalan President Carles Puigdemont_¢ès response to the request will determine what happens next; Rajoy said.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: ìIf Mr. Puigdemont makes clear his wish to respect the law and return institutions to normality; he would end a period of uncertainty; tension and rupture.î Rajoy_¢ès request is a preamble to triggering Article 155 of the Spanish Constitution; a move that would enable him to suspend Catalonia_¢ès devolved government and take over control of its affairs in what would represent an ultimate defeat of the Catalan leadership.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: Spain_¢ès Nuclear Option on Catalonia Is No Quick-Fix for Rajoy Spanish assets rallied on the prospect of an end to the immediate threat of Spain_¢ès breakup.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: The chances of the secession of Catalonia; the country_¢ès largest economic region; retreated on Tuesday at the conclusion of a day of tension as Puigdemont announced his government_¢ès response to an Oct. 1 referendum on independence held in breach of Spanish law.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: While Puigdemont claimed the ballot_¢ès result gave him a mandate to push for independence; he said that he would hold off for a ìfew weeksî to pursue talks with Madrid on Catalonia_¢ès constitutional future.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: Catalan coalition lawmakers later signed what they called a declaration of independence and some; though not all; then signed a document suspending it.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: ìPuigdemont will have nowhere to hide now ìì he won_¢èt be able to hide behind the charade we saw last night;î Angel Talavera; an analyst at Oxford Economics in London; said in an interview.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: ìIf he does clarify it_¢ès independence; then Rajoy applies Article 155; and if he doesn_¢èt his coalition may break up and that could lead to elections.î Spain_¢ès benchmark stock index closed up 1.4 percent; while yields on 10-year bonds dropped 6 basis points to 1.63 percent.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: Catalans Wait Jordi Turull; spokesman for the Catalan government; said that triggering Article 155 would make dialogue impossible.

original: In that case; he said in an interview with regional broadcaster TV3; ìwe have to honor our promise; we_¢èll have to proclaim a republic.î The Catalan chief for territory and sustainability; Josep Rull; said the separatist government was waiting to see if Rajoy accepted its offer for dialogue.

author: Angeline Benoit
original: He added that this wasn_¢èt the time to ask questions; but to give responses; Europa Press cited him as saying in Barcelona.

author: Angeline Benoit

original: ìThe illegal referendum to blow open the Constitution; the unity of Spain and their own Catalan statutes has failed spectacularly;î he said.

original: AFP6:00AM October 12; 2017 Spain has given Catalonia_¢ès separatist leader until next week to clarify whether he intends to push ahead with independence; warning that Madrid would take control of the region if it insisted on breaking away.

author: No author
original: Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has vowed to do everything in his power to prevent Catalan secession following a banned referendum in the region; which remains deeply divided over independence.

author: No author
original: He held an emergency cabinet meeting after Catalonia_¢ès president Carles Puigdemont announced on Tuesday that he had accepted the mandate for ìCatalonia to become an independent state.î Mr Rajoy told politicians in Madrid he was giving Mr Puigdemont until Monday to decide if he really wanted to take the path of independence.

original: ìIt is very important that Puigdemont clarify for the rest of Spaniards if he declared independence yesterday or not;î he said.

author: No author
original: The deadline sets the clock ticking on Spain_¢ès most serious political emergency since its return to democracy four decades ago.

author: No author
original: World leaders are watching closely and uncertainty over the fate of the region of 7.5 million people has damaged business confidence; with several listed firms already moving their legal headquarters to Madrid.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: WORLD NEWS 10/11/2017 12:39 pm ET Updated 12 hours ago Spain Gives Catalans 8 Days To Drop Independence The prime minister_¢ès move could deepen the confrontation between Madrid and Catalonia.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Blanca Rodrç_guez and Sonya Dowsett MADRID/BARCELONA; Oct 11 (Reuters) ì Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy on Wednesday gave the Catalan government eight days to drop an independence bid; failing which he would suspend the Catalonia_¢ès political autonomy and rule the region directly.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: His move could deepen the confrontation between Madrid and the northeastern region but also signals a way out of Spain_¢ès biggest political crisis since a failed military coup in 1981.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Rajoy would probably call a snap regional election after activating Article 155 of the constitution that would allow him to sack the Catalan regional government.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Puigdemont issued a symbolic declaration of independence from Spain on Tuesday night but then immediately suspended it and called for negotiations with the Madrid government.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: ìThe cabinet has agreed this morning to formally request the Catalan government to confirm whether it has declared the independence of Catalonia; regardless of the deliberate confusion created over its implementation;î Rajoy said in a televised address after a cabinet meeting called to consider the government_¢ès response.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: He later told Spain_¢ès parliament the Catalan government had until Monday; Oct. 16 at 0800 GMT to answer.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: If Puigdemont was to confirm he did declare independence; he would be given an additional three days to rectify it; until Thursday; Oct. 19 at 0800 GMT.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Failing this; Article 155 would be triggered.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: It is not yet clear if the Catalan government will answer the requirement but it now faces a conundrum; analysts say.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: If Puigdemont says he did proclaim independence; the central government will step in.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: If he says he did not declare it; then far-left party CUP would probably withdraw its support for his minority government.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: ìRajoy has two objectives: if Puigdemont remains ambiguous; the pro-independence movement will get more fragmented; if Puigdemont insists on defending independence then Rajoy will be able to apply Article 155;î said Antonio Barroso; deputy director of the London-based research firm Teneo Intelligence.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: ìEither way; Rajoy_¢ès aim would be to first restore the rule of law in Catalonia and this could at some point lead to early elections in the region.î The stakes are high ì losing Catalonia; which has its own language and culture; would deprive Spain of a fifth of its economic output and more than a quarter of exports.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Puigdemont had been widely expected to unilaterally declare Catalonia_¢ès independence on Tuesday after the Catalan government said 90 percent of Catalans had voted for a breakaway in an Oct. 1 referendum.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Central authorities in Madrid had declared the referendum illegal and most opponents of independence boycotted it; reducing turnout to around 43 percent.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Madrid responded angrily to Puigdemont_¢ès speech to Catalonia_¢ès parliament; saying his government could not act on the results of the referendum.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: ìNeither Mr. Puigdemont nor anyone else can claim; without returning to legality and democracy; to impose mediation...

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Dialogue between democrats takes place within the law;î Deputy Prime Minister Soraya Saenz de Santamaria said.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Invoking Article 155 to ease Spain_¢ès worst political crisis in four decades would make prospects of a negotiated solution even more remote.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: A spokesman for the Catalan government in Barcelona said earlier on Wednesday that if Madrid went down this road; it would press ahead with steps towards statehood.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: ìWe have given up absolutely nothing...We have taken a time out...which doesn_¢èt mean a step backwards; or a renunciation or anything like that;î Catalan government spokesman Jordi Turull told Catalunya Radio.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Spanish Socialist opposition leader Pedro Sanchez said he would back Rajoy if he had to activate Article 155 and that he agreed with the premier to launch constitutional reform within six months to address how Catalonia could fit better in Spain.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: It was not clear how the Catalan government would respond to that offer.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: MARKET RELIEF Puigdemont_¢ès speech also disappointed supporters of independence; thousands of whom watched proceedings on giant screens outside parliament before sadly leaving for home.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Financial markets; however; were encouraged that an immediate declaration of independence had been avoided.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: After Puigdemont_¢ès speech; Spain_¢ès benchmark IBEX share index rose as much as 1.6 percent; outperforming the pan-European STOXX 600 index.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: The rally propelled the main world stocks index; the MSCI_¢ès 47-country _¢_All-World_¢è index; to a record high.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Spain_¢ès 10-year government bond yield - which moves inversely to the price - dropped 5 basis points to 1.65 percent in early trade; according to Tradeweb data.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: At European Union headquarters in Brussels; there was relief that Spain; the euro zone_¢ès fourth-largest economy; now had at least bought some time to deal with a crisis that was still far from over.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: One EU official said Puigdemont ìseems to have listened to advice not to do something irreversible.î The EU has been cool to Puigdemont_¢ès calls for European mediation.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: The Catalan crisis has deeply divided the region itself as well as the Spanish nation.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Opinion polls conducted before the vote suggested a minority of about 40 percent of residents in Catalonia backed independence.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez
original: Some of Catalonia_¢ès largest companies have moved their head offices out of the region and others were set to follow if Puigdemont had declared independence.

author: Blanca RodrÌguez

author: Michael Stothard
original: Spanish prime minister demands clarity on Catalan independence Rajoy says Puigdemont_¢ès response will dictate events as Madrid weighs _¢_nuclear option_¢è Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy delivers his statement at the Moncloa Palace in Madrid on Wednesday _È AP YESTERDAY by Michael Stothard in Barcelona Spain_¢ès prime minister has opened the way for Madrid to use a constitutional ìnuclear optionî to suspend Catalonia_¢ès autonomy; demanding that the regional government makes clear whether it considers itself independent.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Mariano Rajoy decided to take the first step towards triggering Article 155 of the Spanish constitution; which would give Madrid previously unused powers to take control of Catalonia_¢ès regional government; after an emergency cabinet meeting on Wednesday.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Stepping up pressure on the Catalan government; he has given Carles Puigdemont; the Catalan president; five days to clarify the suspended declaration of independence he made on Tuesday.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Mr Rajoy said his formal request for clarity was ìnecessary when activating Article 155î and would dictate the next steps in the crisis to ìoffer certainty to the citizensî.Using Article 155 to suspend Catalan autonomy would deepen the constitutional crisis in Spain since Catalonia held a contested referendum on independence on October 1.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Spain_¢ès government says Catalonia_¢ès independence drive is unconstitutional.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Mr Puigdemont on Tuesday night stepped back from making a full declaration of immediate independence; calling for more dialogue with Spain to resolve the matter peacefully.

author: Michael Stothard
original: But his speech to the Catalan parliament was ambiguous.At one point he appeared to declare independence; saying he now assumed the ìmandate for Catalonia to become an independent state in the form of a republicî.

author: Michael Stothard
original: But this was followed by a proposed suspension of independence for a ìfew weeksî.

author: Michael Stothard
original: According to Spanish media; Madrid has given Catalonia until Monday to confirm its independence.

author: Michael Stothard
original: The regional government would then be given three more days to rectify its decision before Article 155 would be triggered next Thursday.Meanwhile; there were signs that the government was trying to take some steps to de-escalate the situation.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Pedro Sanchez; the head of the opposition socialists; said on Wednesday that his party and the ruling centre-right PP party had agreed to talks to renegotiate laws governing regional autonomy.

author: Michael Stothard
original: He said there would be six months of talks on reforming the constitution; followed by a debate in parliament; adding that his party wanted a constitutional reform to ìallow for Catalonia to remain a part of Spainî.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Mr Sanchez also said his party was backing Mr Rajoy_¢ès calls for clarification over what Mr Puigdemont said on Tuesday night.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Addressing parliament on Wednesday evening; Mr Rajoy rejected offers of international mediation in the Catalonia crisis; and called for respect of Spanish law.

author: Michael Stothard
original: He said there was ìno possible mediation between democratic law and disobedience and unlawfulnessî.

author: Michael Stothard
original: He also described the crisis as ìone of the most difficult times in our recent historyî.

author: Michael Stothard
original: European Commission viceîpresident Valdis Dombrovskis said that Catalonia_¢ès separatist authorities have appealed to Brussels to help mediate with Madrid but Mr Rajoy has not sought EU help.

author: Michael Stothard
original: ìThe commission is following closely the situation in Spain; and reiterates its earlier call for full respect of the Spanish constitutional order;î he said.

author: Michael Stothard
original: ìWe are supporting the efforts to overcome division and fragmentation; to ensure unity and respect of the Spanish constitution.î German chancellor Angela Merkel_¢ès deputy spokeswoman said any independence declaration by Catalonian institutions would be ìillegal and unacceptable and would find no recognitionî in Germany.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Alfonso Dastis; Spain_¢ès foreign minister; said Mr Puigdemont_¢ès speech amounted to a ìtrick to say one thing and do the oppositeî; without giving further details of the government_¢ès plans.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Mr Puigdemont_¢ès announcement came after his government said that more than 2m people voted in the referendum; most of them favouring independence.

author: Michael Stothard
original: Catalonia has more than 5.3m eligible voters._‚ Under a law passed by the Catalan parliament in the weeks before the referendum; the parliament would declare independence within 48 hours of a Yes vote.

original: Rajoy anuncia el requerimiento a la Generalitat previo a la aplicaciç_n del artç_culo 155 El presidente del Gobierno comparece en Moncloa para una declaraciç_n sin preguntas tras un Consejo de Ministros extraordinario -El Consejo de Ministros ha acordado requerir formalmente al Gobierno de la Generalitat si ha declarado la independencia de Catalunya-; ha afirmado Rajoy Esto es lo que dice el artç_culo 155 de la Constituciç_n El presidente del Gobierno; Mariano Rajoy; ha comparecido este miçÈrcoles en Moncloa para ofrecer en una declaraciç_n institucional sin preguntas tras el consejo de ministros extraordinario.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Y ha anunciado: -El Consejo de Ministros ha acordado requerir formalmente al Gobierno de la Generalitat si ha declarado la independencia de Catalunya.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Este requerimiento es previo a cualquiera de las medidas del Gobierno que puede adoptar al amparo del artç_culo 155 de  nuestra Constituciç_n pretende ofrecer a los ciudadanos la claridad y la seguridad que requiere una cuestiç_n de tanta importancia-.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: La declaraciç_n de Rajoy llega ante la propuesta de independencia en suspenso que hizo este martes en el Parlament el president de la Generalitat; Carles Puigdemont; para buscar una vç_a de diç_logo con el Gobierno central.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: ADVERTISING Rajoy ha insistido en que esta actuaciç_n responde a que - el Gobierno quiere ofrecer certezas a los espaç_oles; especialmente a los catalanes; y quiere evitar la confusiç_n generada por las autoridades de la Generalitat sobre una cuestiç_n que tanto les afecta y les preocupa-.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: El requerimiento es parte del procedimiento previo para poner en marcha esta herramienta constitucional; que permite la intervenciç_n de una autonomç_a por parte del Gobierno central.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Esto es lo que dice el artç_culo 155 de la Constituciç_n: ARTççCULO 155 DE LA CONSTITUCIç_N Si una Comunidad Autç_noma no cumpliere las obligaciones que la Constituciç_n u otras leyes le impongan; o actuare de forma que atente gravemente al interçÈs general de Espaç_a; el Gobierno; previo requerimiento al presidente de la Comunidad Autç_noma y; en caso de no ser atendido; con la aprobaciç_n por mayorç_a absoluta del Senado; podrç_ adoptar las medidas necesarias para obligar a aquella al cumplimiento forzoso de dichas obligaciones o para la protecciç_n del mencionado interçÈs general.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Con este movimiento el Gobierno pasa la pelota a la Generalitat en la bç_squeda de que rectifique su anuncio de seguir por la vç_a de la independencia.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: -La respuesta del seç_or Puigdemont marcarç_ el futuro de los acontecimientos en los prç_ximos dç_as.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Si respeta legalidad se pondrç_a fin a un periodo de ilegalidad; tensiç_n y quiebra de la convivencia.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: El seç_or puigdemont tambiçÈn puede atender a las peticiones que han llegado desde tantos ç_mbitos para recuperar la convivencia armç_nica y la seguridad jurç_dica-.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: -Por mi parte; seguirçÈ actuando como hasta ahora; con prudencia y responsabilidad; y teniendo siempre presente el bienestar de los espaç_oles y catalanes-; ha concluido.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Fuentes de Moncloa no llegaron a precisar el periodo de tiempo en el que el president de la Generalitat deberç_a responder al requerimiento; aunque han asegurado que el cronç_metro empieza a contar desde que se apruebe el acuerdo del consejo de ministros en el BOE.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: El Gobierno de Rajoy llegaba a la reuniç_n del Consejo de Ministros decidido a aplicar   el artç_culo 155 de la Constituciç_n como respuesta a la declaraciç_n de independencia proclamada por Puigdemont en el Parlament y luego suspendida.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Segç_n fuentes del Ejecutivo; el Gobierno barajaba tres escenarios para la reuniç_n de este martes en el Parlament: independencia; independencia con suspensiç_n y elecciones.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Sobre los dos primeros supuestos Rajoy y su equipo habç_an tomado la decisiç_n de responder con el 155.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Durante las semanas de contactos constantes entre Rajoy; Pedro Sç_nchez y Albert Rivera se ha barajado la idea de aplicar el 155 con la intenciç_n de disolver el Parlament y hacer lo mismo con el Gobierno de Puigdemont.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: La decisiç_n obligarç_a a nombrar un Govern en funciones; en quien residirç_a la responsabilidad de convocar elecciones.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: El trç_mite que sigue a la decisiç_n del Consejo de Ministros es complejo.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Tras su decisiç_n; Moncloa tiene que ponerse en contacto con la Generalitat pidiçÈndole que rectifique y dç_ndole un plazo para que haga efectiva la correcciç_n de sus actos.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: Si la respuesta de Barcelona no llega en el plazo requerido; Moncloa se pondrç_ en contacto con el Senado para comunicarle su intenciç_n de aplicar el artç_culo 155.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: El Senado tiene regulado la tramitaciç_n del mecanismo constitucional en el artç_culo 189 de su reglamento.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: No ha sido un Consejo de Ministros fç_cil; ademç_s de la presiç_n por la decisiç_n de las medidas a tomar; el tiempo corrç_a en contra porque los ministros debç_an ir al Congreso a responder a las preguntas de la oposiciç_n en la sesiç_n de control.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: El personal de Moncloa cambiç_ hasta tres veces el escenario donde se iba a celebrar la rueda de prensa segç_n pasaban las horas.

author: Rodrigo Ponce de LeÛn
original: En un primer momento habç_a un atril; posteriormente colocaron una mesa con tres silla y finalmente volvieron a colocar el atril para anunciar la declaraciç_n de Rajoy.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Here's what the hell is going on with Catalan independence Alexandra Ma Oct. 11; 2017; 9:13 AM  587 catalonia puigdemont symbolic declaration of independence Catalonia President Carles Puigdemont signs a ìsymbolicî declaration of independence.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Albert Gea/Reuters Catalonia has declared itself independent _¢´ sort of.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: The Spanish region's leader and parliament have produced a signed ìdeclaration of independenceî _¢´ but; confusingly; say the document does not yet have any force.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Catalan president Carles Puigdemont signed the declaration on Tuesday night after a tense session of the region's parliament.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Although it went further than ever before towards enacting Catalan autonomy; the move was also something of a climbdown; given that Puidgemont had for days been speaking of making a complete and unilateral declaration.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Instead; Puigdemont said that the independence he just declared was immediately suspended in order to give Catalonia time to formalise its exit with the Spanish national government in Madrid.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: A spokesman for the Catalan government has since said that the document is ìsymbolicî; and does not have the legal force required to establish a separate nation.Catalonia vote protest Proîindependence demonstrators lift up a ballot box in Barcelona.Albert Gea/Reuters The almost-declaration has perplexed the Spanish government; prompting them to request that the Catalan government clarify its position before moving ahead.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: In a press conference on Wednesday; prime minister Mariano Rajoy formally requested that Catalonia ìconfirm whether or not it has declared independence.î The crisis follows a referendum last week in which a large majority voted in favour of secession.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Spain maintains that the vote was illegal and does not count.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Madrid has a ìnuclear optionî If Catalonia declares independence; Spain can invoke Article 155 of its constitution; which allows Madrid to take ìnecessary measuresî if an autonomous region declares independence from Spain.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: The article has never been invoked in the Spanish constitution's 39-year history and has been dubbed Madrid's ìnuclear optionî in the Catalonia crisis.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: The ratings agency Moody's said Article 155 was one reason why Catalonia's independence wouldn't take place; according to the Financial Times.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Rajoy said on Wednesday: ìThe response of the Catalonian government [on whether it has declared independence] will determine the events in the next few days.î So was the vote legal or not?

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Mariano Rajoy Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy in 2015.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: REUTERS/Andrea Comas Catalonia says yes; and Spain says no.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: On September 6; Catalonia's regional government passed a local law to allow an independence referendum to take place on October 1.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Prior to the vote; Spain's Constitutional Court ruled that a regional government could not call a referendum because the constitution ìdoes not recognise the right to self-determination and establishes that sovereignty resides with Spanish citizens collectively;î according to the Washington Post.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Regardless; over 2.2 million Catalonians _¢´ or 43% of the region's eligible electorate _¢´ voted overwhelmingly to separate from Spain that day; the BBC said.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Consequences of an independent Catalonia catalonia puigdemont rajoy kissing Demonstrators in Madrid hold a banner depicting Rajoy and Puigdemont kissing; with the words: ìLet's be independent of hate.î Pablo Blazquez Dominguez/Getty An independent Catalonia would not be a member of the European Union; the European Commission said last week.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Major Spanish banks; including Caixabank and Sabatell; also reportedly said they were moving or were considering moving their operations out of Catalonia if the region declares independence.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Catalonia is one of Spain's economic powerhouses; and contributes nearly one-fifth of the country's total GDP.

author: Alexandra Ma
original: Spanish stocks led a rebound in European shares on Wednesday after Puigdemont stopped short of declaring independence; according to Reuters.

author: No author
original: Supporters of independence for Catalonia watch a speech by regional President Carles Puigdemont on a giant TV screen at the Triumphal Arch in Barcelona; Spain; on Tuesday.

author: No author
original: | AFP-JIJI WORLD / POLITICS Spain vows _¢_all options_¢è are open in Catalonia crisis talks AFP-JIJI; AP OCT 11; 2017 ARTICLE HISTORY PRINT SHARE MADRID _¢_ Spain_¢ès government vowed to examine ìall optionsî Wednesday in a crisis Cabinet meeting hours after Catalonia_¢ès leaders said they had a mandate to declare independence but put it on hold; plunging the country into uncertainty.

author: No author
original: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has vowed to do everything in his power to prevent the region_¢ès independence in a dispute that has hurled Spain into its deepest political crisis in decades.

author: No author
original: He has refused to rule out imposing direct rule over the semi-autonomous region _¢´ a move that many fear could lead to unrest.

author: No author
original: Rajoy called an emergency meeting after Catalonia_¢ès President Carles Puigdemont announced on Tuesday that he had accepted the mandate for ìCatalonia to become an independent stateî following a banned referendum earlier this month.

author: No author
original: But in a parliamentary speech that left many confused; Puigdemont immediately called for Catalonia_¢ès independence to be suspended to allow for negotiations with the central government.

author: No author
original: On Wednesday; a government source who refused to be named said ìall optionsî were on the table as the crisis talks were underway.

author: No author
original: Thanks to its constitution; adopted in 1978 following decades of civil strife and dictatorial rule; Spain is one of the Western world_¢ès most decentralized nations.

author: No author
original: It has 17 semi-autonomous regions with varying degrees of control over issues such as education and health care.

author: No author
original: But Article 155 of the Constitution allows the central government to take some or total control of any of its 17 regions that don_¢èt comply with their legal obligations.

author: No author
original: Article 155 says that if a region_¢ès government breaches its constitutional obligations or ìacts in a way that seriously threatens the general interest of Spainî; Madrid can ìtake necessary measures to oblige it forcibly to comply or to protect said general interest.î At stake is the future of a region of 7.5 million people deeply divided over independence; one of Spain_¢ès economic powerhouses; whose drive to break away has raised concern for stability in the European Union.

author: No author
original: Crowds of thousands gathered outside the parliament building in Barcelona on Tuesday evening; waving Catalan flags and banners screaming ìdemocracyî in the hope of witnessing a historic night in a region that remains deeply divided over independence.

author: No author
original: But Spain_¢ès political establishment rounded on Puigdemont following his declaration; and support among separatists in Catalonia was mixed.

author: No author
original: The government stuck to its stance that it would not accept mediation or any talks until Catalan leaders drop their independence bid.

author: No author
original: ìMr. Puigdemont _¢´ no one _¢´ can expect to impose mediation without returning to legality or democracy;î Deputy Prime Minister Soraya Saenz de Santamaria told reporters.

author: No author
original: She said Puigdemont was ìa person who doesn_¢èt know where he is; where he_¢ès going or with whom he wants to go.î Barcelona resident Maria Rosa Bertran said she was against a delayed secession.

author: No author
original: ìI find it even worse because it is suffering a longer agony.

author: No author
original: Indecision and uncertainty is the worst thing that can happen to us;î she told AFP.

author: No author
original: Following his declaration to parliament; Puigdemont and his allies signed an independence declaration outside the chamber; but its legal validity was unclear.

author: No author
original: Spain and Catalonia now enter into the unknown; as Madrid has repeatedly said independence is not up for discussion.

author: No author
original: Catalonia pressed ahead with an independence referendum on October 1 that the central government said breached Spain_¢ès constitution.

author: No author
original: Spanish police cracked down on the polls; beating some voters as they closed down polling stations.

author: No author
original: ìI did not expect independence to be declared today because of all the processes that the government of Spain has begun; both with police actions and with threats;î Marc Cazes; a student in Barcelona; said on Tuesday.

author: No author
original: Around 90 percent of those who cast ballots voted for independence but the poll was poorly monitored and many Catalans opposed to secession boycotted it.

author: No author
original: The crisis has caused deep uncertainty for businesses in one of the wealthiest regions in the eurozone_¢ès fourth-largest economy.

author: No author
original: A string of companies have already moved their legal headquarters _¢´ but not their employees _¢´ from Catalonia to other parts of the country.

author: No author
original: But on Wednesday morning; the Spanish stock market was up 1.16 percent on hopes for a breakthrough in the crisis.

author: No author
original: The standoff has also put strain on the euro.

author: No author
original: The single currency was up after Puigdemont_¢ès announcement and held onto gains in Asian trade on Wednesday; buying $1.1815.

author: No author
original: But it was still down two cents from its recent highs seen last month; due to the political uncertainty.

author: No author
original: Stephen Innes; head of Asia-Pacific trading at OANDA; said that while the euro rose it ìgained little traction as this is little more than kicking the can down the road.

author: No author
original: It_¢ès unlikely we_¢ève heard the last of this debate despite cooler heads prevailing.î Demands for independence in Catalonia; which has its own language and cultural traditions; date back centuries.

author: No author
original: But a 2010 move by Spain_¢ès Constitutional Court to water down a statute that gave Catalonia additional powers; combined with a deep economic meltdown in Spain; sparked a surge in support for independence.

author: Ciaran Giles
original: Spain gives Catalonia five days to clarify independence statement; threatens to curtain region_¢ès autonomy Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy asked for clarity Wednesday in response to an announcement from the president of the Catalonia region; Carles Puigdemont; that he was proceeding with a declaration of independence but was suspending it for several weeks to facilitate negotiations.

author: Ciaran Giles
original: By CIARAN GILESThe Associated Press Wed.; Oct. 11; 2017 MADRID_¢´Spanish authorities gave Catalonia_¢ès separatist leader five days to explain whether his ambiguous statement on secession was a formal declaration of independence and warned Wednesday that his answer dictated whether they would apply never-used constitutional powers to curtail the region_¢ès autonomy.

author: Ciaran Giles
original: Threatening to invoke a section of the Spanish Constitution to assert control over the country_¢ès rogue region; Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy said Catalan president Carles Puigdemont_¢ès response to the central government_¢ès ultimatum would be crucial in deciding ìevents over the coming days.î Puigdemont announced on Tuesday that he was using the victory in a banned Oct. 1 referendum to proceed with a declaration of Catalan independence; but proposed freezing its implementation for a few weeks to allow for dialogue and mediation with the government in Madrid.

author: Ciaran Giles
original: His equivocal position seemed designed to appease the most fervent separatists; but also to build support _¢´ both in Catalonia and internationally _¢´ by provoking another tough response from Rajoy_¢ès Cabinet.
